prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the author of the WIBTA (Would I Be Terrible for Asking) post is in the wrong. The author is considering kicking out their 19-year-old stepdaughter who lives with them. 

First, I need to understand the situation. The author is in a long-term relationship with their fiancé, not married. The stepdaughter is 19, works at a salon, and has been living with them since she was 18. The author tried to build a relationship but felt ignored, especially when they bought her a car. Now they want her to move out, and they don't care how she reacts. The fiancé might be upset but the author thinks it's for the best.

So, the key points here: The stepdaughter is an adult, over 18, and financially independent (has a job). The author is not her parent, just a stepparent. The question is whether they have the right to ask her to leave. Legally, if the stepdaughter is an adult and not under the care of the author, they can't just kick her out without cause, especially if she's paying rent or contributing. But the situation here is that the author is providing her a place to stay, perhaps as part of the living arrangement with their fiancé. 

But the author is not her legal guardian. The fiancé (who is her biological mother) is the one who allows her to stay. So if the author is living in a shared household where the stepdaughter is staying with her mother's consent, the author might not have the authority to unilaterally decide she has to leave. The author is in a de facto marriage, but not legally married. The mother's approval is key here. 

The author's frustration is understandable—they want their own space. However, the stepdaughter is an adult and may have the right to stay if the mother allows it. The author's approach of not caring how she takes it might be seen as harsh, especially if the stepdaughter hasn't been given a choice or a timeline. Also, the car gift and the stepdaughter's indifference add to the tension. 

Legally, unless there's a lease agreement or something that specifies the stepdaughter's tenancy, the author might not have the legal standing to tell her to leave. Emotionally, the author is justified in feeling this way, but acting on it without considering the mother's role and the stepdaughter's autonomy could be problematic. 

So, the author is in a position where they are not the legal parent, and their authority is limited. They might be overstepping if they try to remove the stepdaughter without the mother's agreement. Therefore, the answer might be that the author is in the wrong because they don't have the legal or ethical authority to kick out an adult who is staying with her mother's permission.
